project.name: kernel
project.description: The Gentoo Kernel project has the goal of bringing a stable and consistent kernel feature set across all architectures supported by Gentoo Linux

longdescription.p: With an ever increasing userbase, which is constantly demanding a higher quality distribution the demand for stable, professionally managed kernel sources are very important. Because we as users want the best from Gentoo Linux we supply a selection of generic and specialised sources.

In order to provide a rich choice of high quality kernel trees Gentoo Linux must combine and test several kernel patches before they can offer finished ebuilds to the users. This is where the Gentoo Kernel Project comes into play.

goals.p: The Gentoo Kernel Project aims to deliver the best possible experience from its sources across all supported architectures. By having a clearly set management team with published objectives, established time lines, and project accountability, the project will help bring the end-user experience for our kernels to even higher levels.

extrachapter.title: Other Kernels (not patched by Gentoo Kernel Project)

body.p: The Gentoo Kernel project provides ebuilds for other linux kernels such as vanilla-sources, ck-sources, mm-sources, usermode-sources etc. Most of these are not patched by Gentoo in any way, and therefore are provided as a courtesy.
Each subproject must make sure that the kernel ebuilds they provide adhere to the following quality demands:

ul.li: Each kernel ebuild must compile and work on as many systems as possible before committing to the Portage tree (even if package.mask is used).
Each kernel ebuild should not have Gentoo-specific bugs on http://bugs.gentoo.org/ in the last 1-2 weeks after being released before moving from ~ARCH to ARCH
Every kernel-tree released by the Gentoo Kernel Project must have a clear description on what it provides and what philosophy is behind it's existence

Any kernel feature that has a userspace utility, must have the appropriate userspace utility ready for inclusion in portage before the kernel is released (ie. evms2, freeswan, USAGI,...). All packages should be released at the same time.

body.p: As kernels continue to develop in a vast pace, the Gentoo Kernel Project must make sure that it keeps track of all kernel trees it provides so that our users will receive the latest and greatest kernel trees in a timely fashion without losing the quality they are accustomed to.

The Gentoo Kernel Project cannot guarantee that the provided kernel ebuilds work on your system, but will rectify any faults with supported sources. Some sources (upstream sources) cannot be supported.

As with most projects, the Gentoo Kernel Project and it's subprojects use a roadmap to inform the users and developers about current development items, near-future integrations, seeable future enhancements and far future proposals.
In order for our users to be able to pick the best kernel ebuild we provide them with a Kernel Guide in which all available kernel ebuilds are listed and described.
